snippet: With Republicans in control of the State Senate in Colorado, the funding for the licensing program was largely stripped, leaving applicants waiting. And in New Mexico, the governor wants to repeal the law allowing the licenses.
abstract: State-by-state battles over programs granting driver's licenses to noncitizens have played out in absence of any broad federal legislation over how to handle millions of undocumented immigrants; in Colorado, where Republicans are now in control of State Senate, licensing program has been stripped of its operating budget, and New Mexico's governor wants to repeal state law allowing such licenses.

byline.original: By JACK HEALY and JULIE TURKEWITZ
byline.contributor: Rick Rojas contributed reporting from Phoenix.

lead_paragraph: With Republicans in control of the State Senate in Colorado, the funding for the licensing program was largely stripped, leaving applicants waiting. And in New Mexico, the governor wants to repeal the law allowing the licenses.

headline.main: Unauthorized Immigrants’ Access to Driver’s Licenses Is at Risk
headline.print_headline: Unauthorized Immigrants’ Access to Driver’s Licenses Is at Risk
